div.div: There are Linux distribution that don’t have Graphical Interfaces, so you must learn to navigate easily from the file system from command line first. So, go ahead, install Linux on your computer or run it with Virtual Machine. After the installation press Ctrl,Alt + T, and I will wait for you in the next chapter.
This command is used for knowing where you are on the file system.
Lists all items in the current directory.
Change directory command is used to move through the file system.
Yhe commands mkdir and rmdir are making and deleting directories.
The commands touch and rm are creating and deleting files.
The commands cp and mv are coping and moving files through the file system.
Here is a table with five of the most used Linux commands:

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Just like Windows and Mac, Linux is an operating system. It is created by Linux Torvalds who was designed the core of the operating system back when he was a student for one of his classes. It is based on UNIX, but it has a greater success, because of the great community, open-source and hey, it is free!

Open source means that you have unlimited access to the code and you can design everything as you want. And for that reason there are hundreds of different interpretations for Linux, that are called Distributions or distros. Distros may be represent as different flavors, from one User Interface to another, they may have different settings but from the inside they are still Linux. Here is List of the most common ones:
- Ubuntu
- Linux Mint
- Debian
- Fedora
- Open Suse

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Shell is a program in Linux, which reads an given input from the user {command and parameters} and based on that input gives an output. Shell can be runed from both GUI and CLI.

There are Linux distribution that don’t have Graphical Interfaces, so you must learn to navigate easily from the file system from command line first. So, go ahead, install Linux on your computer or run it with Virtual Machine. After the installation press Ctrl,Alt + T, and I will wait for you in the next chapter.

div.p: There are Linux distribution that don’t have Graphical Interfaces, so you must learn to navigate easily from the file system from command line first. So, go ahead, install Linux on your computer or run it with Virtual Machine. After the installation press Ctrl,Alt + T, and I will wait for you in the next chapter.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: This command is used for knowing where you are on the file system.

section.p: You must have installed Linux or run it with through a virutal machine
You must have opened the terminal with the combination of Ctrl+Alt+T or from the menu → terminal
The first command from this chapter is going to be one of the most important ones. It simply says:

Print Working Directory. As we know the directory is just a file, which is representing a content, or dynamic linking with flag which tells us that this file is a directory. We can move through the system when we are going to such a file. So pwd will basically print the current directory which we are in at the moment.

li.span: Open Linux Terminal
Enter the command pwd
Type Enter

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Lists all items in the current directory.

section.p: You must have installed Linux or run it with through a virutal machine
You must have opened the terminal with the combination of Ctrl+Alt+T or from the menu → terminal

div.section:
ls is short for list and it does as it says. It lists every file in the current directory.
Q: For example I have a directory named “A”, and in it there are files called “a1”,”b1”.
What will be the output from the terminal when I give the input “ls” ? A: The answer is simple. It depends. Read once again the description for the command pwd and you will now why it depends. So if we are in currently in the location of A it will display a1, b1. Otherwise the answer is: what is having in the directory of {pwd}.

li.span: Open Linux Terminal
Enter the command ls
Type Enter

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: So after we have a concept about the file system and the commands pwd and ls, it is time to know about Linux permissions and command options, flags:

div.div:
Here we are on our way to learn more about Linux.
So basically, Permissions is what are the accessibilities from the users to the files.
There is the One User which has all the rights and it is called Super User, but for that later.
On our computer there can be many users that are can access the file system. But how to control access for all of them? The answer is by putting them in a groups and describe which groups have access. This is controlled by a bit mask.
Everything in Linux is files!
Permissions:
1 – execute
2 – write
3 – write and execute
4 – read
5 – read and execute
6 – read and write
7 – read, write and execute – full accessibility. The bit masking is done by this 8 numbers (0 – has no access to the file). This numbers represents the words read, write, execute, and by bits are 0, 1, 0 – cannot do {read, write or execute} 1 – can do. So if we want the user to can read and execute the number is 5 and it is calculated by 0 and 1s read write execute 1 0 1 -> by 10’s system is equal to 5. That is how it is calculated.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Flags are simply options to the commands. As far we know how to list the files that are in the current directory. It is done by ls command. We also know a little bit about permissions. So let’s see how we can see the permissions on the files. It is done by giving the command ls a flag l – for long
ls -l
Now we can see a list of files with their permissions and there are rwe (read write execute),
but why are they repeated 3 times.
It is because the permissions are grouped by: Owner of the file rights, Group Rights, Other Rights.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: That’s cool, but how to see which command, which options have ?

The answer is man. The Linux embedded manual for short man is a command where you can find the all information for Linux in one place. Without using of internet, it is on your computer and it is available 24/7. And it is a command.
Q:But how to use man?
A1: First try to understand it by yourself. Think. If you not manage to understand the answer it will be provided by A2.
A2: man man – how tricky 😊

div.p: Change directory command is used to move through the file system.

section.p: You must have installed Linux or run it with through a virutal machine
You must have opened the terminal with the combination of Ctrl+Alt+T or from the menu → terminal

The cd or change directory is used to move through the file system easily. For example if there you are located in the Downloads and there is directory called potato and you want to go there you have to enter the command cd potato

li.span: Open Linux Terminal
Type the command cd
Type the name of the directory you want to enter as a first parameter of the command
Press Enter
List all of the directories to make sure you are on the right direcotory

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Yhe commands mkdir and rmdir are making and deleting directories.

section.p: You must have installed Linux or run it with through a virutal machine
You must have opened the terminal with the combination of Ctrl+Alt+T or from the menu → terminal

div.section: Make directory or mkdir is basically making a directory and place it on your current locationRemove direcotry or rmdir Just like mkidr only it is doing the opposite thing.

li.span: List the current directory as it is shown on chapter 5 (on page )
Type mkdir command
Then type name as you want for directory
Press Enter and you will see after you list again, that the new directory is there
Then type rmdir and the name of the directrory that you created on step 4
Press Enter and you will see after you list, that the directory has been deleted.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: The commands touch and rm are creating and deleting files.

section.p: You must have installed Linux or run it with through a virutal machine
You must have opened the terminal with the combination of Ctrl+Alt+T or from the menu → terminal
touch is using for two things. The first purpose is to make file by doing
touch <name of the file> and it place an empty file in your current location. And the second thing it does is to change the -last modified time of the file to the time when the command is executed.

The command rm or remove is used to remove a single file from your current locations. Just provide the command a parameter – the name of the file which you want to be removed and it is done. The most common used flags of the remove command are -r and -f -r -> recursively it removes every file from the directory of your choice . -f -> force, without asking for permissions on every step of the deleting process. Try rm -rf / 😊 or Or don’t ! // It will remove our your files including the Linux OS.

li.span: Open Linux terminal
Type the comand touch and then the name of the file you want to create or update
Press Enter
After you list the items in the current directory you will seethat the file is either created or updated
Type the command rm, to remove the file you recently created, then type the name of the file
Press Enter
You will see, as you list the items in the current directory, that your file is deleted.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: The commands cp and mv are coping and moving files through the file system.

section.p: You must have installed Linux or run it with through a virutal machine
You must have opened the terminal with the combination of Ctrl+Alt+T or from the menu → terminal

div.section:
Cp for copy and mv for move are commands which are used to organize your files in other directories and copy their content.
the syntax is:
cp <file to be copied> <where to be copied> Mv <file to be moved> <where to be moved> * the mv command can be used also to rename files.

li.span: Open Linux Terminal
Make a file, like it is described on the previous chapter
Type the command cp to copy the file
Type as a First parameter the name of the file that you are going to copy
Type as a Second Parameter the location which you want the file to be copied at.
Press Enter
Go to the location which you provided on step 5.
After you list the elements of the current directory, you will find out that there is a copy of the original file.

div.p: Here is a table with five of the most used Linux commands:

tr.td: It is the most powerfull searching tool.
It is used to change the permissions of specific file.
This command terminates a proccess → kill {PID}
It is used to indentify the user, which is currently loged.
This command outputs the content of the given file.
